results.title: Good buy
results.creator_credit: Jill Robb, Yoram Gross, South Australian Film Corporation and Yoram Gross Films
results.brief_description: This animated consumer education film reveals both bad buying habits of customers and the ploys of modern marketing. It is pointed out that in buying situations the facts presented may not be quite as true as they seem, and that careful deliberation is always a good policy including the necessity of obtaining a guarantee and the reading of fine print in any signed agreement.

results.creator_credit: Joan Dick, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Days I'll remember in South Australia
results.creator_credit: Howard Rubie, Peter Dimond and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The star quality of the state of South Australia and one of its daughters, Julie Anthony, is revealed in this prestigious tourist film. Specially conceived music, and superb visuals combine to present the major tourist attractions of South Australia. The River Murray, Port Lincoln, the Barossa Valley, the Adelaide Hills, the Flinders Ranges, and the city of Adelaide are featured. Julie Anthony’s singing adds a special dimension to the whole film

results.title: Day of the wag
results.creator_credit: John Dick, Malcolm Smith, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The problem of truancy is the subject of this film. Various factors contributing to truancy are raised for discussion, not the least of which is the common adult practice of taking a sickie. Cast includes Sue Berny, Judy Dick, Joe DiSario, Doug Gautier and others.

results.title: Skilled craftsmen: five Australians
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A lot of people consider craft a hobby. Something which is undertaken as a source of relaxation and self fulfilment. Many people, however, treat the crafts as a professional livelihood. This film shows the lifestyle of five of these people, each illustrating a different facet of the crafts: Joe McBain, a blacksmith; David Wright, a stained glass artist; Lilija Duks, a weaver; Greg Wain and Victoria Howlett, potters. Narrated by Rod Mullinar

results.title: Safe food handling
results.creator_credit: Leigh Tilson, Leigh Tilson and Associates and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the need for care when handling food. Disease free handlers, working with well maintained equipment is essential, otherwise food born illness can occur.

results.title: The Children's Programme
results.brief_description:
In 1978 disadvantaged primary schools in the Northern Metropolitan area of Melbourne received supplementary grants programme which provided funding with the aim to enable greater equality of opportunity and develop closer ties with parents and the community. Featured is Lyndall Hall, a sub-school of Brunswick East High School and a camp held at Halls Gap. The Northern Metropolitan area covers the muncipalities of Coburg, Preston, Northcote, Heidelberg, Broadmeadows, Whittlesea and Eltham. 79 schools in this region are classiified as disadvantaged. Includes interview with Phillip Chislett from Northcote High Scool, Jan Andrews, Jan Cleeland and Bruce Westerman from Camp Meadows Primary School.

There are some sound issues.

results.title: Who Does the Sentence?
results.creator_credit: Mark Laidler, Peter Johnson, Coburg State College and Victorian association for the care and resettlement of offenders
results.brief_description: When a person is taken into custody, the family of the offender serve “a sentence” of another kind. The Victorian Association for the Care and Rehabilitation of Offenders (VACRO) tries to help these families in its own individual fashion. The film is noted for scenes actually filmed in Pentridge

results.title: Thing of Beauty
results.brief_description: The restoration of the interior of Parliament House, Melbourne is a time-consuming and delicate process-making replicas and replacing the Victorian baroque moulded plaster decorations, applying gold-leaf less than a thousandth of an inch thick, retouching the highlights of the mouldings and repainting the walls and surrounds with the original sky-blue - but the result is both eccentric and splendid
